Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Multicolored Planar Algebras and Quadrilaterals of Subfactors

POR.DRECONTENT:
In joint work with Grossman and Snyder, we confirmed the hypothesis that the unitary 2-category coming from a lattice of finite index II_1-subfactors has the structure of a multishaded planar algebra. This result should pave the way for applications of planar techniques to the study of lattices of subfactors. Grossman, Snyder, and I are continuing to study the 2-category associated to a lattice of subfactors. This should lead to more topological invariants and connections with mathematical physics.

In joint work with Deprez and Yamashita, we constructed an infinite index subfactor with finite dimensional higher relative commutants. Besides being an important example in its own right, this example is a gateway to studying the tower of higher relative commutants for an infinite index subfactor. This is the first step in the study of infinite index subfactors, where hardly anything is known, and advancements will lead to a wealth of knowledge on von Neumann algebras.

Subfactors are important to study because they have deep connections to (quantum) groups, knot invariants, topological quanfum field theories, conformal field theories, and mathematical physics. Fusion categories (coming from small index subfactors) are the simplest model of systems of particles which merge and split. There is some scientific evidence that we physically observe these models in the Fractional Quantum Hall Effect, which has been studied for the development of a topological quantum computer. While this application is still within the world of science and engineering, its implications and outreach would extend far beyond these boarders. As we continue to work on projects related to subfactors, planar algebras, and fusion categories, we keep in mind the big picture of scientific advancement, along with the important questions of why the world works the way it does.
